title: Alfredo Palacios
text:
Alfredo Lorenzo Palacios (August 10, 1880 – April 20, 1965) was an <a href="Argentina">Argentine</a> <a href="socialism">socialist</a> <a href="politician">politician</a>.
Palacios was born in <a href="Buenos%20Aires">Buenos Aires</a>, and studied <a href="law">law</a> at <a href="University%20of%20Buenos%20Aires">University of Buenos Aires</a>, after graduation he became a <a href="lawyer">lawyer</a> and taught at the university until becoming a <a href="dean%20%28education%29">dean</a>. 
In 1902, he was elected to the Buenos Aires' legislature, and in 1904, to the <a href="Argentine%20Chamber%20of%20Deputies">Chamber of Deputies</a> for the 4th Circunscription of Buenos Aires, which corresponded to the "<a href="Neighbourhoods%20of%20Buenos%20Aires">barrio</a>" of <a href="La%20Boca">La Boca</a>, thus becoming the first socialist in the Argentine Congress and in the American continent. Palacios helped create many laws including the "Palacios Law" ("Ley Palacios") against sexual exploitation, and others regulating <a href="child%20labor">child</a> and women labor, working hours and Sunday rest.
Palacios was elected <a href="Argentine%20Senate">Senator</a> in 1932, serving until the Senate was dissolved in 1943, and in 1955 was appointed ambassador to <a href="Uruguay">Uruguay</a>. In 1960, Palacios was elected again as Senator, and as <a href="Argentine%20Chamber%20of%20Deputies">Deputy</a> in 1963.
